title: Data-Efficient Pretraining with Group-Level Data Influence Modeling
author: Zichun Yu (Carnegie Mellon University), Fei Peng (Meta), Jie Lei (Meta), Arnold Overwijk (Meta), Wen-tau Yih (Meta), Chenyan Xiong (Carnegie Mellon University)
relevance_why: The methods proposed for optimizing data selection based on group-level influences can be adapted to enhance data selection strategies for audio and speech tasks, such as developing smarter models for audio generation or language processing that rely on curated datasets.
background: Data-efficient pretraining involves selecting the most effective training data to improve model performance while reducing pretraining costs.
contribution: This paper introduces Group-Level Data Influence Modeling to optimize data selection for pretraining, achieving significant performance improvements on downstream tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically relied on individual data influence assessments without accounting for group interactions, which led to suboptimal data selection.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon existing approaches by modeling data influences at the group level, leading to better data curation strategies.

key_innovation: The method uses relational data influence models that not only evaluate individual data points but also consider the relationships between them, enhancing the understanding of data interactions.
real_world_impact: This framework has the potential to optimize how language models are pretrained, leading to better-performing AI systems with reduced resource requirements.
limitations: No limitations were explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.group-level influence: **Group-level influence** refers to the combined effect of a set of data points on the performance of a machine learning model, as opposed to assessing each data point independently.
new_terms.influence-aware clustering: **Influence-aware clustering** is a technique for grouping data based on their relational influence, ensuring that training data within clusters exhibit stronger interactions.
